Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Algorithmic Challenges and Opportunities in Spatial Data Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Spatial data takes many forms including configuration spaces of robots or proteins, collections of shapes or measures, and physical models and measurements from new sensing technologies. These data sets often contain intrinsic, nonlinear, low-dimensional structure hidden in complex high-dimensional input representations.<br/> To uncover such structure one needs to adapt to local changes in scale, recognize multiscale structure, represent the intrinsic space underlying the data, compute with coarse approximate distances, and integrate heterogeneous data into meaningful distance functions. There is a need for algorithms and data structures that can search, represent, and summarize such data sets efficiently. The PI will develop new data structures, models of computation, sampling theories, sampling algorithms, and metrics for addressing these challenges.<br/> <br/> The specific aim of the project is to adapt hierarchical metric data structures to work with locally adaptive distances using new models of computation that only use approximate distance comparisons. These models acknowledge the reality that with sufficiently complex data, even a single distance computation can be expensive. A second specific aim is to develop new multiscale sampling theories as well as new algorithms for computing such samples. These samples and sampling algorithms will be applicable to a wide range of problems and will extend and generalize greedy and farthest-point strategies. A third specific aim is to develop algorithms for new metrics and distance functions for heterogeneous data to more accurately represent intrinsic structure in data. These algorithms will generalize methods used in both Voronoi refinement mesh generation and topological data analysis.<br/><br/> The project will make geometric methods applicable to a much wider range of problems and with that comes the need for wider understanding of advanced geometry and topology. The PI will integrate research and education, introducing computer science students at both the undergraduate and graduate level to foundational ideas in spatial data analysis, from geometry to topology. The PI will also work one-on-one to mentor undergraduates from traditionally underrepresented groups and help train high school teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to invent new algorithms and data structures to analyze metric data. This is data that has a notion of distance or similarity. It is a ubiquitous problem in many areas of computing. A particular focus of the project was to work with complex, high-dimensional metric spaces, where even a single distance computation can be expensive. This is an area where good theoretical ideas have a great impact.

 

The project resulted in several research breakthroughs including new efficient data structures for proximity search problems in general metric spaces, new methods to analyze metric algorithms, and new paradigms for sampling metric data sets. Most of our research into data structures was directed toward search problems. We invented efficient data structures that are dramatically simpler than previous work while achieving the same theoretical guarantees for important problems such as nearest neighbor search, range search, and kth nearest neighbor search. This work is important for bridging the gap between what is possible in theory and what is possible in practice.

 

The research also intersected with the field of topological data analysis (TDA). In TDA, the resulting data often lie in a complex, infinite-dimensional metric space. This is exactly the setting where our new research is most useful. For example, we showed how and when methods invented for low-dimensional problems can still be effective in an infinite-dimensional setting.

 

Another critical challenge with very complex metric data is to summarize it. We developed several new algorithms to efficiently produce different kinds of summaries in the form of samples with good metric properties. In particular, we gave new algorithms for several variants of greedy sampling. Unless P=NP, it achieves the best approximation to the metric k-center problem that can be computed in polynomial time. We invented new, simple, efficient algorithms for computing the greedy permutation as well as variants that adapt to the underlying density.

 

There were substantial broader impacts of this project. Many of the research results were accompanied by open-source implementations. This code was released publicly on GitHub and disseminated through the standard Python packaging system. Three PhD students were trained to participate in professional research and completed their degrees funded by this project. Two more Ph.D. students were funded by this project and are currently working towards their degrees. Also, a Master's student was trained as part of this award. New course content was created and released publicly to a wide audience via Youtube receiving over 70,000 total views. Another broader impact came from a summer training program where middle school, high school, and community college teachers were trained by the PI to take ideas from computational geometry back to their classrooms.
